4. Continue: 11-20 in the second row. Notice: 11 is right below 1!
5. Work through as far as the child can manage (at least 1-50).
6. Look at patterns: 'What do you notice about the columns?'

slides.heading: The Hundred Board
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, we're going to learn about numbers today! This is a special board that helps us see all the numbers from one all the way to one hundred. It's like a big number adventure!

slides.setup_instructions: Place the board on a mat. Spread number tiles in a box or pile.
slides.mascot_explanation: To start our number adventure, we need some special friends. See this big board with little squares? That's our Hundred Board. And these little squares with numbers on them are our Number Tiles – they have all the numbers from 1 to 100! We'll put them all on the board.

slides.text: 'This board can hold ALL the numbers from 1 to 100! Let's fill it up.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this big board! It's like a special puzzle for numbers. We are going to fill it up with all the numbers we know, from the little number one all the way to the big number one hundred. Let's get ready to put them in their special spots!

slides.text: Start with 1: top left corner. 2 next to it. Continue: 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now let's put the first numbers in their homes. We start with number one right here in this first little box. Then number two goes right next to it, and we keep going, filling up this first row with numbers one, two, three, and so on, all the way to ten!

slides.text: Second row: 11. 'Where does 11 go? Right below 1!' Continue to 20.
slides.mascot_explanation: We're doing so great! Now we start the next row with number eleven. See how eleven goes right underneath number one? We keep going and fill this row with numbers up to twenty, just like we did with the first row.

slides.text: 'Look at the first column: 1, 11, 21, 31... they all end in 1! What about the last column?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's peek at the numbers we've already put down. Look at this straight up and down line of numbers: 1, 11, 21. They all have a '1' in them! Now you look at the last line of numbers and tell me what you see.

slides.prompt: Fill in as much of the hundred board as you can. Look for patterns: what do you notice about the rows and columns?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the number explorer! See how many numbers you can put in their right spots on the board. As you put them down, look for fun patterns, like how the numbers go across and up and down. You can fill as much as you can!

slides.text: 'The hundred board shows us how numbers are organized. There are so many patterns hiding in there!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child place numbers correctly on the hundred board (at least 1-50)?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such an amazing job filling up our number board! You saw how all the numbers fit together like a giant puzzle. We learned that numbers have special patterns, and you found so many of them! Isn't that cool?

parent_notes: The Hundred Board is a treasure trove of mathematical patterns. Rows count by ones. Columns count by tens. Diagonals create other patterns. Don't point out all patterns at once — let the child discover them over many sessions. This material can be revisited for weeks: find all the odd numbers, find all numbers with 5, fill in only certain numbers. If you don't have a hundred board, draw a 10x10 grid and use number cards.

title: Celebrations Around the World — Chinese New Year
description: Learning about Chinese New Year (Lunar New Year), one of the world's most celebrated holidays. Exploring traditions of red decorations, dragons, and family feasts.
instructions:
1. Find China on the globe (Asia, yellow continent).
2. 'Chinese New Year is the biggest celebration in China! It happens in January or February.'
3. Show pictures: red lanterns, dragon dances, firecrackers, red envelopes with money.
4. Explain: 'Red is the lucky color. People clean their homes, eat special foods, and give red envelopes.'
5. Make a simple paper lantern: fold red paper, cut slits, form into a cylinder.
6. Talk about the Chinese zodiac: 'Each year has a different animal!'

slides.heading: Celebrations
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to learn about a super fun party called Chinese New Year. It's a big celebration where people have lots of fun!

slides.setup_instructions: Print or display celebration pictures. Have red paper ready for lantern craft.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need some special things to learn all about Chinese New Year! We need a globe to find a faraway place, some pretty pictures, red paper, scissors to cut, and glue to stick things together. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find these for our activity?

slides.text: Find China on the globe. 'China is in ASIA — the yellow continent. More than a billion people live there!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's find China on this big round globe! See this yellow part? That's where China is, and lots and lots of people live there!

slides.text: 'Chinese New Year is a time for family, food, and celebration. The color RED is everywhere because red means LUCKY!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Chinese New Year is a very happy time when families get together. They use the color red everywhere because red means good luck! Isn't that exciting?

slides.text: Show pictures: dragon dances, lanterns, fireworks, red envelopes. 'Families clean their house to sweep away bad luck.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at these amazing pictures! We see colorful dragons dancing, pretty lights called lanterns, and loud fireworks. People also give special red envelopes filled with good wishes!

slides.prompt: Make a paper lantern: fold red paper in half, cut slits from the fold, open, roll into a cylinder, and tape. Add a handle!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to make our very own lantern! We'll take the red paper, fold it, make some cuts, and then roll it up to make a pretty lantern. It will look so special!

slides.text: 'Chinese New Year celebrates family, luck, and new beginnings. What a wonderful tradition!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain key Chinese New Year traditions and locate China on the globe?
slides.mascot_explanation: We learned so many cool things about Chinese New Year today, like how red is lucky and how families celebrate together. You did such a great job exploring this fun celebration!

parent_notes: Chinese New Year is an excellent cultural study because it involves many child-friendly elements: bright colors, animals (zodiac), crafts (lanterns), and special foods (dumplings). Making a paper lantern is a simple craft that connects to the tradition. If possible, visit a local Chinese restaurant or neighborhood during the celebration. The Chinese zodiac animals fascinate children — find which animal represents the child's birth year.

title: Read-Aloud: Frederick by Leo Lionni
description: Reading 'Frederick' by Leo Lionni, a gentle story about a mouse who collects words, colors, and sunshine while others gather food for winter.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'What do you see? What is this mouse doing?'
2. Read aloud, pausing to let the child observe Lionni's collage illustrations.
3. When the other mice question Frederick, ask: 'What do you think he's doing?'
4. After reading, discuss: 'What did Frederick collect? Was it important?'
5. Talk about different kinds of work — gathering food AND gathering beauty.
6. Invite the child to collect words or colors like Frederick.
materials_needed: Optional: paper and crayons for collecting colors

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, we're going to read a special story today! It's called Frederick, and it's about a little mouse. We get to learn all about what Frederick does.

slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready. Set out art supplies if desired.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need our special Frederick book for our story today! If you want to draw like Frederick later, we can also get out some paper and crayons. Just ask a grown-up to help you find them.

slides.text: Cover: 'This is Frederick. He's a field mouse. What do you think his story is about?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Here's the cover of our book! See the little mouse? That's Frederick. What do you think he might be doing in his story? It's fun to guess!

slides.text: Read with a warm, gentle tone. Pause at the illustrations — Lionni's torn-paper collage style is distinctive.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to read the story together! Listen closely to the words and look at the pretty pictures. They are made in a special way, like a puzzle!

slides.text: When Frederick shares his words and colors: 'How did the other mice feel? Did Frederick's collection help them?'
slides.mascot_explanation: The other mice are asking Frederick what he's doing! How do you think they feel? Do you think what Frederick is collecting is important for them?

slides.prompt: Be like Frederick! Go around the room and collect three colors you see. Collect two sounds you hear. Share them like a poem.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's play like Frederick! Can you find three colors you see around you? And what two sounds can you hear right now? Let's say them together like a special poem!

slides.text: 'Frederick reminded us that words, colors, and stories are just as important as food. What would you collect?'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain what Frederick collected and why it mattered?
slides.mascot_explanation: Frederick showed us that stories and colors are super important, just like food! What other things do you think are important to collect, like Frederick did? You did such a great job listening!

parent_notes: Frederick celebrates the value of art, poetry, and imagination alongside practical work. Leo Lionni's collage illustrations are perfect for discussing art techniques. The story introduces the idea that different contributions matter — a wonderful Montessori value of respecting each person's unique gifts.
